request_pathways.name: SWA Authorization to Release Protected Health Information

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (image-only scan, revised Sept 2021)
Entity reference list (not an ROI form)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form from the medical release page, prints and hand-fills it, and submits via unspecified method; 'Personal Use' is one of several purpose checkboxes but the form is structured for third-party release.

red_flags: Witness signature required on all forms — HIPAA does not require witnesses for authorization or access requests
Last 4 digits of SSN collected unnecessarily — MRN and DOB suffice for identity verification
Form-2 is an image-only scan (no text layer, no fillable fields) uploaded in 2025 — a regression from the digital-native form-1
Fragmented form landscape: separate forms for hospital vs. ambulatory entities with no guidance on which to use
bright_spots: Granular record type selection with 10+ categories and individual date range fields
Electronic delivery explicitly offered alongside Paper and CD
'Personal Use' listed as an explicit purpose option, acknowledging patient self-access
Verisma online portal offered as an alternative digital pathway

findability.rationale: Level 3: The medical release page is reachable via site navigation (Patient & Visitors → Medical Release) and web search, but multiple overlapping forms without clear labeling require moderate effort to identify the correct one.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: The primary downloadable forms have zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite completion; no submission instructions appear on the forms themselves, creating a primarily paper workflow despite a Verisma portal existing as a separate alternative.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Logical numbered structure with good record-type granularity, but moderately legalistic language, dense sensitive-information notice, and fragmented multi-form landscape create notable clarity problems.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic authorization form by checking 'Personal Use' and writing their own name as recipient, but the form was not designed for self-access — no Right of Access language, no simplified flow, and the third-party release structure requires patients to figure out which parts apply.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Witness signature requirement and partial SSN collection go beyond what HIPAA requires for patient access; non-conditioning statement is present but no fee disclosure, no response timeline, and no patient rights statement.

overall.summary: Southwell provides findable but paper-oriented authorization forms with a generic third-party release structure, witness requirement, and fragmented multi-form landscape that create moderate barriers for patients seeking their own records.
